the dormitories and the new

summer. Construction of additional facilities and renovation

BY STEPHANIE REYNOLDS
The Baltimore Zoological Society (BZS) is sponsoring an
international symposium May 19—May 22 on the lion-tailed
macaque, a critically endangered species of primate. The symposium will include a keynote address on survival plans for endangered species by William Conway, General Director of the New
York Zoological Society. Conway will speak at 7:30 p.m., May
19 in Shriver Hall; the rest of the symposium will take place at
the Zoo.
The lion-tailed macaque lives in a group of evergreen rain
forests in southwest India. Between 195 and 800 now live in the
wild and the number is dropping. Another 289 exist in zoos
around the world. The Baltimore Zoo houses the second largest
collection of lion-tailed macaques in the world. (The largest is
the Prince Ranier collection in Monaco.)
Dr. Paul Heltne, chairman of the BZS research committee
organizing the symposium, described the purpose of the meeting
as "not only an exchange of information and the publications
which will result. . .but also to develop a survival strategy for the
lion-tailed macaque both in the wild and- in captivity." The
symposium will feature 'speakers from India and from several
American zoos that have collections of the lion-tailed macaque.
Though most of the symposium focuses on the lion-tailed
,macaque, the keynote speaker will discuss how zoos can work
with each other and with their governments to protect all endangered species.
The keynote address is open to the public. Admission is $3
or $2 for senior citizens, students and members of the BZS. For
ticket reservations, call the BZS at 467-4387.

After the so-so run of Blake
Edwards' S.O.B. (more so what than so
good), Edwards has once again set out to
master the comedic form. His new film,
Victor/Victoria, has been remade from a
1933 German production of Viktor und
Viktoria. Although the source of the new
film is not original, Edwards has in no
way copied the first.
Edwards has finally come up with
a vehicle for his wife, Julie Andrews.
With Disney movies such as Mary Poppins
and The Sound of Music behind her,
Andrews has had difficulty coming up
with less wholesome roles. S.O.B. broke
that tradition, and all the moviegoing
world was shocked with a revealing view
of Andrews' breasts. Perhaps this baring
was just a sneak preview for Victor/
Victoria: after the S.O.B. scene, one can
understand how Andrews can pose as a
man and not be discovered until she is
espied unclothed.
Victor/Victoria is set in Paris in
1934 with Andrews in the starring role(s).
She is a down and out coloratura looking
for work in a transvestite cabaret when
she encounters Toddy (Richard Preston),
an over-the-hill entertainer and professed
homosexual. He gives her shelter, lends
her his ex-lover's clothes, and thereby hits
upon an inspiration: to make Victoria a
woman impersonating a man impersonating a woman. To make it in "gay"
Paris, one needs a gimmick — and this
becomes hers.
As Count Victor of Poland,
Victoria rises, to the top. Andrews is
exquisite as a performer, and cabaret, as
depicted in the movie, seems to be her
forte. She switches from male to female
character untroubled by the transition,
and her voice is a complement to. the
lavish musical numbers she is in. Of
course, trouble always arises when things
seem to be running smoothly, and we
find Victoria at odds with herself over her
deception of so many people, culminating
in a central problem — she falls in love.
James Garner, as love interest and
millionaire financier King, is at his most
winning, Bret Maverick best. This macho,
Mafia-connected type falls in love with
the woman he sees on stage, but who

reveals herself to be a man off. Although
the macho stereotype is central to
Garner's character, King is well-rounded.
His means of dealing with what seems to
be his "latent homosexual tendencies"
brings joke after joke and homosexual
after homosexual out of the closet.
One of the most interesting
aspects of the film is how it deals with
homosexuality. Homosexuality is not
looked down upon, although stereotypes
are parodied and gay jokes are a dime a
dozen. Homosexuals are portrayed in
almost every possible light, in roles that
are both stereotypic and quite the contrary. While Toddy may call himself a
"pour' and make numerous jokes seemingly at the expense of hisPown dignity,
he is the only character totally at peace
with his own sexuality.
The drag queens that we see only
briefly are .wonderful, and the zeal with
which they break into a brawl undermines any derogatory throughts on their
"sissy" attire. One of the principal
characters that comes out of the closet
does so in a funny, moving scene. The
only completely dislikable gay character
is Toddy's ex-lover, who has a haughtyaristocratic air and the personality of an

person.

Victor/Victoria is high camp. It is
more of a laughable yarn than a social
commentary, although I did find myself
wondering what happened (might have

missing a number of realistic elements.

know that the setting is Paris, that the
people look French (some of them,

simple cafes, stark apartments. The
twistings and turnings of a somewhat
complicated plot make up for these
technicalities in substance. On the whole.
Victor/Victoria is one of those shouldn'tbe-missed films.

The Last Word on Baltimore's Architecture
cont. from p. 13
tectural history from the past, through
the present, and into the future.
The roots of the Modern Movement begin early in the nineteenth
century with the association of architectural style and taste with social change
and morality. The assumption of Gothic
romanticism asserted a social reform
against the moral and social decay of the
industrial revolution by the restatement
of Christian ideals. In the effort to
transform the social status-quo, architectural style and planning has alternated
between the extremes of regulated
planned utopias on the one hand, and a
denunciation of harsh historical realities
of industrialization on the other. These
are the ideas and conceptions through
which architects have approaced the
problem of building, particularly in a city
such as Baltimore which has primarily
grown up during the nineteenth and
twentieth centuries. More than anything
else, Baltimore architecture retains the
history of this movement and holds its
heritage for its people and the nation.
In an attempt to restore architecture to its classical virtue, the Roman and
Greek ideals were revived for their
structural form and function as well as
their aesthetic grace. Many are aware of
Jefferson's contributions to this style, as
well as the Bostonian attempts of the
Federalist style with Bulfinch in the
Massachusetts State House. However,
Baltimore architecture and its architects
brought this nation some of the greatest
examples of Neo-Classicism. On the
Hopkins campus, Homewood House
exhibits Baltimore's best example of a
The
Federal period country house.
classical porticos and palladian details
give elegant detail to this small building.
Its architect, William Thornton, went on
to do the first design for the Capitol
Building in Washington. His remaining
works are few, and the restoration of
Homewood House marks an important
move for Hopkins' contribution to
architectural history.
Yet probably one of the greatest
masterpieces in the Neo-Classical style is
Benjamin Latrobe's Cathedral of the
Assumption.
Latrobe submitted two
designs, one Classical and one Gothic, of
which the classical was accepted. In it
Latrobe recreates Latin-cross plan with a
domed central space reminiscent of
Soufflot's Pantheon in Paris. In the
building, Latrobe clarifies Roman forms
in simplified geometric patterns which
pervade this massive structure. Another
example of Latrobe's work can be seen in
the small Greek temple in the gardens of
the Baltimore Museum of Art.
Latrobe's contributions to the
field of American architecture are numerous. Latrobe was the first professionally
trained American architect. He introduced the practice of paying architects a
percentage of the building cost. In
addition, his style and restoration abilities
rebuilt the Capital and the White House
as well as various other national buildings
after the War of 1812, creating the
buildings as we know them today.
Within one block of Latrobe's
cathedral stands another monument of
the neo-classical style, the Unitarian
.Church. The building stands within a
stark white rectilinear facade and an
arcaded columnar porch. Inside, the
building opens up with a large pantheonlike dome supported by four pendentives
(semi-domes) which break up the building
into its essential cross type structure.
The architect, Maximilian Godegroy,
went on to design the Battle Monument
downtown, as well as the first Gothic
revival church in the country, St. Mary's
Chapel at St. Mary's Seminary.

After the first generation of
Neo-classical architects came one of
Latrobe's students, Robert Mills. Mills
designed the Washington Monument at
Mount Vernon Place. The first monument to Washington, it was one of the
first American uses of the column as a
memorial. form. From this, Mills would
go on to create the Washington Monument in the capital which one architectural critic of the time would call "the
national phallic symbol." Neither of the
plans were completed under his original
designs, probably to the artistic advantage
of the monuments.
Neo-classical design would last in
Baltimore long after the modern movement had swept most of the rest of
world. Much of the surviving public
architecture surrounding the campus
eminates from the talent of a man whO
was probably the last great classical
architect in this country — John Russell
Pope. The Baltimore Museum of Art,
University Baptist Church and the Scottish Rite Temple of Free Masonry display
his mastery of form and style which made
Russell Pope one of the most brilliant and
contraversial architects of his time.
Pope's artistic genius.as well as his individual courage lay in his determination to
preserve the classical artistic form and the
perfect manipulation of symmetrical
geometric space in a functional piece of
architecture. Pope is also noted for
having designed the old wing of the
National Gallery and the Jefferson
Memorial in Washington.
Among Pope's other distinctions.
are his drawings for the Hopkins campus.
Although none of his building designs
were ever executed, the axial site plan of
the campus remains essentially his creation. One of his particularly notable
designs for this campus was a huge
rotundaed building to be placed where
the Eisenhower Library now stands, the
sketches for which were recently sold at
some of the highest prices ever paid for
architectural drawings. If Pope's plans
had been executed, Johns Hopkins might
have had a campus of the highest architectural distinction. Instead many of the
buildings stand as second rate Georgian
copies.
Gothic _revival revolted against the
classical rationalism in the adoption of
more romantic ideals. Although Latrobe's Gothic design for the cathedral
was not accepted, Gothic architecture
soon made its debut on the American
scene with Godefroy's chapel for St.
Mary's Seminary. Although Godefroy
did not truly understand the principles of
Gothic architecture, he was able to
master the use of the arch. The chapel
constitutes a unique mixture of gothic
and classical design into a tiny and
graceful artistic structure. Much of the
Gothic elements were added as decoration, but it represents one of the first
attempts at "the Gothic" in American
architecture.
After the completion of Godefroy's church, the Gothic revival took a
large place in Baltimore architecture. The
first American master of the style, A.J.
Davis, was commissioned by Robert
Gilmore to create designs for his estate.
From this was created Glen Ellen, one of
the greatest examples of domestic Gothic
architecture built in this country. Today
its foundations stand beneath Loch
Raven Dam; but from its example and
from Davis' training, much of Baltimore's
church architecture took shape. The son
of a local architect, Robert Long grew up
with this tradition, leading him to design
the gates to Greenmount Cemetery, St.
Alphonsus Church and Franklin Street
Presbyterian, beginning the Gothic heritage in this city. Two unique monuments
of this style are to be found firk in the

Greenmount Cemetery chapel, the octagonal and morass of flying buttresses,
and second in the Mount Vernon Place
Methodist Church's contrasting green
serpentine and red sandstone exterior and
Victorian Gothic interior. From these
emerge numerom examples of Gothic
church architecture whose towers stretch
across the city and line its streets.
The intentions of the Gothic
revival were not made evident only in the
Gothic style. Richard Upjohn, another
major Gothic revival architect, built one
of the primary monuments of Italian
romantic design. This was Wyman Villa,
which formally stood on campus behind
Garland Hall. It has since been replaced
by a parking lot. The only remaining
portion standing is the Gatehouse which
presently lodges the Hopkins NewsLetter. Another example of the style
which still exists in the city is Johns
Hopkins' own home, 'Clifton'. A remodeled farmhouse made into a villa, its
brick walls covered by plaster form
massive structures of arcades, towers and
rich decor. The floors are richly paved in
marble, and the ceilings lift to enormous
heights of over twenty feet. Originally
left by Hopkins in his will to be the site
of the University and hospital, this estate
was sold to the city, and is presently used
for administrative functions and the
grounds as a public golf course.
Another Romantic piece of Baltimore architecture (and a classic in Baltimore history) is the Bromo Selzer Tower,
often confused on Art History exams
with the Palazzo del Vecchio in Florence.
With the growth of Baltimore, the
domain of the architect came to be not
merely the promotion of an ideological
style. Indeed, the city's industry and
population was growing, and the problems of the.amount and types of architecture needed to be solved. One of the
solutions came in the materials for
architectural usage. Baltimore was the
first American city to use iron in industrial architecture, beginning with the Sun
Building, with iron romanesque facades
bolted to the two ends of the buildings.
The only remaining example in the city is
the Robins Paper Building near the
Bromo Selzer Tower. With industry and
commerce came the industrialists like
Johns Hopkins and Peabody, resulting in
the creation of familiar institutions. Of
these two, the Peabody Institute made
original use of cast iron as supporting and
decorative elements. The iron interior
supports the outside marble design in the
creation of a classical and elegan facade.
Upon entering the Peabody-Pratt Library,
the cast iron interior seems to take over
in a glorious decorative rise of six balconies supporting books. The endless
agglomeration of ironwork demonstrates
Baltimore's unique mastery in this art — a
mastery which was transported across the
world. The flowing staircase and thin
supports carry the burden of developing a
new style and technique in engineering
and architectural design.
The problems of population in an
eastern city were solved in the age-old
solution of row houses. The entire city is
pervaded with endless streets of these
brick and brownstone structures. Some
of those located a few blocks beneath the
train station show Romantic traces of
stone decoration, with jutting towers and
bay windows. On the other hand, some
(particularly from the 500 to 900 blocks
of St. Paul) flow slowly down the street
in variations of minute detail. The city's
most beautiful examples are the brownstone houses which line Mount Vernon
Place across from the Peabody Conservatory.
Another solution lay in planned
communities. Roland Park was America's

Latrobe 's Cathedral of the Assumption
first planned suburban development community. Developer's regulated the cost of
the houses, distance from the street,
dimensions of the lots, placement of
fences and often the status of who could
live there. The plans included the first
suburban shopping center, a community
golf course, churches, and various other
attributes. During most of the community's history, the architectural firm of
Wyatt and Noltez controlled many of the
designs. As a result, this small neighborhood became one of Baltimore's most
respected and elegant communities.
When Modernism hit Baltimore, it
did it in grand style. Modern architecture
made itself most evident in the city in the
1950s. With a few exceptions such as a
small house by Frank Lloyd Wright
beyond Roland Park, Charles Center and
the Inner Harbor launched the city into
the center of Modern architecture as we
know it today. Modernism readopted the
rationalism of classicism but in a utilitarian, functionalist mode. One Charles
Center by Mies van der Rohe rises from a
landscaped plaza in clean and direct lines
of Dark Brown alumnium and gray-tinted
glass. With this building and Highfield
House, located on Charles Street, Mies
defines his own aesthetic sense of modern
rectalinearity with a steel, glass and

is the tallest free-standing cantalevered
building in the world. Yet its interior
rooms form small units of usable space
with an almost common and unimaginative attention to detail.
The building with the greatest

forested roofs echo the wavy motion of
the harbor as this motif is repeated in the
neon waves lighting up the harbor landscape. The tiled sides bring color to the
bland architectural styles of modernism
and hint of the post-modern revolution in
architecture.
The open-space steel
pyramid attached to the prominent
section of the building reveals the sculp7
tural quality of space in design as in the
work of Michael Graves. Indeed, the
back side of the building recalls the point

These are the latest facets of Baltimore
architecture: where will it go from here?

control over the rest. THEN

the students and conceal the fact

sole control over a lot of money.

course, argue that they have
always had the power to ignore
the SAC,but that this is the first

true. Past Councils have had the

extra bucks into their pet

-increase over their appropriations for the last two years. The

rational justification, the SAC
wisely voted to cut out this

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern
BY MICHAEL SEGAL
Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are
still alive when they begin Rosencrantz
and Guildenstern Are Dead by flipping
coins. They watch head after head land.
Rosencrantz (Bruce McKenzie) wins coin
after coin, which makes Guildenstern
(Don Gordon) question just what is
happening, and why it is happening in
such a random, desolate spot. All the
audience has to go on at first is that these
characters were "sent for" and, for the
time being, that is enough.
Before we get a chance to tire of
Guildenstern's mental meanderings, a
troupe of tragedians/prostitutes arrive,
led by the Player, played by Malcolm
Shelley (whose hair was a discrete grandmotherly blue the night that I saw it,
although it should be a more arresting
shade by opening night). The players as a
group are explosive all evening long.
Shelley looked a little frozen early in the
performance, especially when fixed to
one spot on the stage by a spotlight. But
when he began directing, or more precisely, ordering his little band of players,
he comes alive, twisting his body and his
face until the audience is at a loss to
discern whether he is upset or merely
solioquizing. By the time he gets around
to dying near the end of the play (I'm not
giving away the plot; he dies several times
and there's no way of telling which death
is the real one), the audience is completely taken in by him, and the harsh spotlight is no longer a hindrance but a
complement to his contorted face.
He is backed up by a collection of
active players, who always keep the
background entertaining and generally
keep the stage in motion. Gary Miller
displays an almost frightening array of

BY DOREEN MORAN
After the so-so run of Blake
Edwards' S.O.B. (more so what than so
good), Edwards has once again set out to
master the comedic form. His new film,
Victor/Victoria, has been remade from a
1933 German production of Viktor und
Viktoria. Although the source of the new
film is not original, Edwards has in no
way copied the first.
Edwards has finally come up with
a vehicle for his wife, Julie Andrews.
With Disney movies such as Mary Poppins
and The Sound of Music behind her,
Andrews has had difficulty coming up
with less wholesome roles. S.O.B. broke
that tradition, and all the moviegoing
world was shocked with a revealing view
of Andrews' breasts. Perhaps this baring
was just a sneak preview for Victor/
Victoria: after the S.O.B. scene, one can
understand how Andrews can pose as a
man and not be discovered until she is
espied unclothed.
Victor/Victoria is set in Paris in
1934 with Andrews in the starring role(s).
She is a down and out coloratura looking
for work in a transvestite cabaret when
she encounters Toddy (Richard Preston),
an over-the-hill entertainer and professed
homosexual. He gives her shelter, lends
her his ex-lover's clothes, and thereby hits
upon an inspiration: to make Victoria a
woman impersonating a man impersonating a woman. To make it in "gay"
Paris, one needs a gimmick — and this
becomes hers.
As Count Victor of Poland,
Victoria rises, to the top. Andrews is
exquisite as a performer, and cabaret, as
depicted in the movie, seems to be her
forte. She switches from male to female
character untroubled by the transition,
and her voice is a complement to. the
lavish musical numbers she is in. Of
course, trouble always arises when things
seem to be running smoothly, and we
find Victoria at odds with herself over her
deception of so many people, culminating
in a central problem — she falls in love.
James Garner, as love interest and
millionaire financier King, is at his most
winning, Bret Maverick best. This macho,
Mafia-connected type falls in love with
the woman he sees on stage, but who

reveals herself to be a man off. Although
the macho stereotype is central to
Garner's character, King is well-rounded.
His means of dealing with what seems to
be his "latent homosexual tendencies"
brings joke after joke and homosexual
after homosexual out of the closet.
One of the most interesting
aspects of the film is how it deals with
homosexuality. Homosexuality is not
looked down upon, although stereotypes
are parodied and gay jokes are a dime a
dozen. Homosexuals are portrayed in
almost every possible light, in roles that
are both stereotypic and quite the contrary. While Toddy may call himself a
"pour' and make numerous jokes seemingly at the expense of hisPown dignity,
he is the only character totally at peace
with his own sexuality.
The drag queens that we see only
briefly are .wonderful, and the zeal with
which they break into a brawl undermines any derogatory throughts on their
"sissy" attire. One of the principal
characters that comes out of the closet
does so in a funny, moving scene. The
only completely dislikable gay character
is Toddy's ex-lover, who has a haughtyaristocratic air and the personality of an
over-ripe eggplant. He is, however, a real
person.

Victor/Victoria is high camp. It is
more of a laughable yarn than a social
commentary, although I did find myself
wondering what happened (might have
happened) to all those terrific gay characters at the onset of World War II. It is
difficult, though, to take the film seriously at any point simply because it is
missing a number of realistic elements.
For one, there are no French accents..
This leads to some confusion when you
know that the setting is Paris, that the
people look French (some of them,
anyway), and yet they all speak English.
Any sense of realism is ultimately lost
because of this.
Another problem is the set. It is,
perhaps, the most unauthentic set I have
seen in recent film. If it weren't for the
fact that the movie is pure farce, I would
wonder what kind of job the set director
actually did. The backdrops of Paris look
like plywood and rubber cement creations — they draw unnecessary attention
to themselves. Only the interiors of these
buildings seem natural: lavish cabarets,
simple cafes, stark apartments. The
twistings and turnings of a somewhat
complicated plot make up for these
technicalities in substance. On the whole.
Victor/Victoria is one of those shouldn'tbe-missed films.

the present, and into the future.
The roots of the Modern Movement begin early in the nineteenth
century with the association of architectural style and taste with social change
and morality. The assumption of Gothic
romanticism asserted a social reform
against the moral and social decay of the
industrial revolution by the restatement
of Christian ideals. In the effort to
transform the social status-quo, architectural style and planning has alternated
between the extremes of regulated
planned utopias on the one hand, and a
denunciation of harsh historical realities
of industrialization on the other. These
are the ideas and conceptions through
which architects have approaced the
problem of building, particularly in a city
such as Baltimore which has primarily
grown up during the nineteenth and
twentieth centuries. More than anything
else, Baltimore architecture retains the
history of this movement and holds its
heritage for its people and the nation.
In an attempt to restore architecture to its classical virtue, the Roman and
Greek ideals were revived for their
structural form and function as well as
their aesthetic grace. Many are aware of
Jefferson's contributions to this style, as
well as the Bostonian attempts of the
Federalist style with Bulfinch in the
Massachusetts State House. However,
Baltimore architecture and its architects
brought this nation some of the greatest
examples of Neo-Classicism. On the
Hopkins campus, Homewood House
exhibits Baltimore's best example of a
The
Federal period country house.
classical porticos and palladian details
give elegant detail to this small building.
Its architect, William Thornton, went on
to do the first design for the Capitol
Building in Washington. His remaining
works are few, and the restoration of
Homewood House marks an important
move for Hopkins' contribution to
architectural history.
Yet probably one of the greatest
masterpieces in the Neo-Classical style is
Benjamin Latrobe's Cathedral of the
Assumption.
Latrobe submitted two
designs, one Classical and one Gothic, of
which the classical was accepted. In it
Latrobe recreates Latin-cross plan with a
domed central space reminiscent of
Soufflot's Pantheon in Paris. In the
building, Latrobe clarifies Roman forms
in simplified geometric patterns which
pervade this massive structure. Another
example of Latrobe's work can be seen in
the small Greek temple in the gardens of
the Baltimore Museum of Art.
Latrobe's contributions to the
field of American architecture are numerous. Latrobe was the first professionally
trained American architect. He introduced the practice of paying architects a
percentage of the building cost. In
addition, his style and restoration abilities
rebuilt the Capital and the White House
as well as various other national buildings
after the War of 1812, creating the
buildings as we know them today.
Within one block of Latrobe's
cathedral stands another monument of
the neo-classical style, the Unitarian
.Church. The building stands within a
stark white rectilinear facade and an
arcaded columnar porch. Inside, the
building opens up with a large pantheonlike dome supported by four pendentives
(semi-domes) which break up the building
into its essential cross type structure.
The architect, Maximilian Godegroy,
went on to design the Battle Monument
downtown, as well as the first Gothic
revival church in the country, St. Mary's
Chapel at St. Mary's Seminary.

After the first generation of
Neo-classical architects came one of
Latrobe's students, Robert Mills. Mills
designed the Washington Monument at
Mount Vernon Place. The first monument to Washington, it was one of the
first American uses of the column as a
memorial. form. From this, Mills would
go on to create the Washington Monument in the capital which one architectural critic of the time would call "the
national phallic symbol." Neither of the
plans were completed under his original
designs, probably to the artistic advantage
of the monuments.
Neo-classical design would last in
Baltimore long after the modern movement had swept most of the rest of
world. Much of the surviving public
architecture surrounding the campus
eminates from the talent of a man whO
was probably the last great classical
architect in this country — John Russell
Pope. The Baltimore Museum of Art,
University Baptist Church and the Scottish Rite Temple of Free Masonry display
his mastery of form and style which made
Russell Pope one of the most brilliant and
contraversial architects of his time.
Pope's artistic genius.as well as his individual courage lay in his determination to
preserve the classical artistic form and the
perfect manipulation of symmetrical
geometric space in a functional piece of
architecture. Pope is also noted for
having designed the old wing of the
National Gallery and the Jefferson
Memorial in Washington.
Among Pope's other distinctions.
are his drawings for the Hopkins campus.
Although none of his building designs
were ever executed, the axial site plan of
the campus remains essentially his creation. One of his particularly notable
designs for this campus was a huge
rotundaed building to be placed where
the Eisenhower Library now stands, the
sketches for which were recently sold at
some of the highest prices ever paid for
architectural drawings. If Pope's plans
had been executed, Johns Hopkins might
have had a campus of the highest architectural distinction. Instead many of the
buildings stand as second rate Georgian
copies.
Gothic _revival revolted against the
classical rationalism in the adoption of
more romantic ideals. Although Latrobe's Gothic design for the cathedral
was not accepted, Gothic architecture
soon made its debut on the American
scene with Godefroy's chapel for St.
Mary's Seminary. Although Godefroy
did not truly understand the principles of
Gothic architecture, he was able to
master the use of the arch. The chapel
constitutes a unique mixture of gothic
and classical design into a tiny and
graceful artistic structure. Much of the
Gothic elements were added as decoration, but it represents one of the first
attempts at "the Gothic" in American
architecture.
After the completion of Godefroy's church, the Gothic revival took a
large place in Baltimore architecture. The
first American master of the style, A.J.
Davis, was commissioned by Robert
Gilmore to create designs for his estate.
From this was created Glen Ellen, one of
the greatest examples of domestic Gothic
architecture built in this country. Today
its foundations stand beneath Loch
Raven Dam; but from its example and
from Davis' training, much of Baltimore's
church architecture took shape. The son
of a local architect, Robert Long grew up
with this tradition, leading him to design
the gates to Greenmount Cemetery, St.
Alphonsus Church and Franklin Street
Presbyterian, beginning the Gothic heritage in this city. Two unique monuments
of this style are to be found firk in the

Greenmount Cemetery chapel, the octagonal and morass of flying buttresses,
and second in the Mount Vernon Place
Methodist Church's contrasting green
serpentine and red sandstone exterior and
Victorian Gothic interior. From these
emerge numerom examples of Gothic
church architecture whose towers stretch
across the city and line its streets.
The intentions of the Gothic
revival were not made evident only in the
Gothic style. Richard Upjohn, another
major Gothic revival architect, built one
of the primary monuments of Italian
romantic design. This was Wyman Villa,
which formally stood on campus behind
Garland Hall. It has since been replaced
by a parking lot. The only remaining
portion standing is the Gatehouse which
presently lodges the Hopkins NewsLetter. Another example of the style
which still exists in the city is Johns
Hopkins' own home, 'Clifton'. A remodeled farmhouse made into a villa, its
brick walls covered by plaster form
massive structures of arcades, towers and
rich decor. The floors are richly paved in
marble, and the ceilings lift to enormous
heights of over twenty feet. Originally
left by Hopkins in his will to be the site
of the University and hospital, this estate
was sold to the city, and is presently used
for administrative functions and the
grounds as a public golf course.
Another Romantic piece of Baltimore architecture (and a classic in Baltimore history) is the Bromo Selzer Tower,
often confused on Art History exams
with the Palazzo del Vecchio in Florence.
With the growth of Baltimore, the
domain of the architect came to be not
merely the promotion of an ideological
style. Indeed, the city's industry and
population was growing, and the problems of the.amount and types of architecture needed to be solved. One of the
solutions came in the materials for
architectural usage. Baltimore was the
first American city to use iron in industrial architecture, beginning with the Sun
Building, with iron romanesque facades
bolted to the two ends of the buildings.
The only remaining example in the city is
the Robins Paper Building near the
Bromo Selzer Tower. With industry and
commerce came the industrialists like
Johns Hopkins and Peabody, resulting in
the creation of familiar institutions. Of
these two, the Peabody Institute made
original use of cast iron as supporting and
decorative elements. The iron interior
supports the outside marble design in the
creation of a classical and elegan facade.
Upon entering the Peabody-Pratt Library,
the cast iron interior seems to take over
in a glorious decorative rise of six balconies supporting books. The endless
agglomeration of ironwork demonstrates
Baltimore's unique mastery in this art — a
mastery which was transported across the
world. The flowing staircase and thin
supports carry the burden of developing a
new style and technique in engineering
and architectural design.
The problems of population in an
eastern city were solved in the age-old
solution of row houses. The entire city is
pervaded with endless streets of these
brick and brownstone structures. Some
of those located a few blocks beneath the
train station show Romantic traces of
stone decoration, with jutting towers and
bay windows. On the other hand, some
(particularly from the 500 to 900 blocks
of St. Paul) flow slowly down the street
in variations of minute detail. The city's
most beautiful examples are the brownstone houses which line Mount Vernon
Place across from the Peabody Conservatory.
Another solution lay in planned
communities. Roland Park was America's

Latrobe 's Cathedral of the Assumption
first planned suburban development community. Developer's regulated the cost of
the houses, distance from the street,
dimensions of the lots, placement of
fences and often the status of who could
live there. The plans included the first
suburban shopping center, a community
golf course, churches, and various other
attributes. During most of the community's history, the architectural firm of
Wyatt and Noltez controlled many of the
designs. As a result, this small neighborhood became one of Baltimore's most
respected and elegant communities.
When Modernism hit Baltimore, it
did it in grand style. Modern architecture
made itself most evident in the city in the
1950s. With a few exceptions such as a
small house by Frank Lloyd Wright
beyond Roland Park, Charles Center and
the Inner Harbor launched the city into
the center of Modern architecture as we
know it today. Modernism readopted the
rationalism of classicism but in a utilitarian, functionalist mode. One Charles
Center by Mies van der Rohe rises from a
landscaped plaza in clean and direct lines
of Dark Brown alumnium and gray-tinted
glass. With this building and Highfield
House, located on Charles Street, Mies
defines his own aesthetic sense of modern
rectalinearity with a steel, glass and
concrete structure of precise definitions
similar to those of the doric order. From
here the Morris Mechanic Theater by
John Johansen explodes into a multitude
of concrete forms announcing his style of
brutalism. As one approaches the building, one sees the remaining textures of
the wood mold, the straight, geometric
forms confronting the viewer. Indeed,
Johansen's art will again loom over the
city in the huge new oval Meyerhoff
Theater which emulates the symphony
hall in Berlin. As one approaches the
harbor, the two towering buildings of the
USF&G building and the World Trade
Center dominate their surroundings. The
World Trade Center, designed by the firm
of 1.M. Pei,is a pentagonal building which
is the tallest free-standing cantalevered
building in the world. Yet its interior
rooms form small units of usable space
with an almost common and unimaginative attention to detail.
The building with the greatest
architectural style and elan is the National Aquarium. The large pyramidical
forested roofs echo the wavy motion of
the harbor as this motif is repeated in the
neon waves lighting up the harbor landscape. The tiled sides bring color to the
bland architectural styles of modernism
and hint of the post-modern revolution in
architecture.
The open-space steel
pyramid attached to the prominent
section of the building reveals the sculp7
tural quality of space in design as in the
work of Michael Graves. Indeed, the
back side of the building recalls the point
of the new wing of the National Gallery.
These are the latest facets of Baltimore
architecture: where will it go from here?
